questions.question_text: Which statement is true regarding the audit user account? (Choose two.)

choices.E: The audit user has read-write access to the NSX Manager.
choices.A: The admin user must set the password for the audit account to log in to NSX Manager.
choices.C: The audit user must be created and have its password changed to log into the NSX Manager.
choices.D: The administrator must run the set audit user password <password> command.
choices.B: The administrator must run the set user audit password <password> command.

comments.content:
that audit user gets activated/enabled by changing the password. SO...from that link, the directions are:

"To activate it, log in as admin and run the set user audit password command and provide a new password. When prompted for the current password, press the Enter key." 

Therefore A&B are true.

from that same article, "The audit user has read privileges to the NSX-T environment and is not active by default. " So E is completely out the window. The audit user does NOT have read-write.
Article in the link clearly points to BE

questions.question_text: Where do you configure the VLANs used in VRF Lite? (Choose two.)

choices.C: downlink interface of the default Tier-0 gateway
choices.A: uplink interface of the default Tier-0 gateway
choices.D: uplink interface of the VRF gateway
choices.E: segment connected to the Tier-1 gateway

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
https://nsx.ninja/index.php/Configure_NSX-T_VRF_Lite seems to be a very complete article.

Selected Answer: BC
Let's break this down

A. supports ECMP - No. Equal Cost Multi Pathing is for North South routing and thus is a T0 gateway thing.

B. owned and configured by the Tenant - Potentially? Who is to say you're working for a medium sized business and the operator and tenant are the same? This is just a bad question. T1 gateways are scoped towards this function which is why this is a "close" answer.

C. always configured in active-standby mode - Yes, T1 gateways are always active/standby mode.

D. owned and configured by Service Provider - Potentially... again, it's a bad question. "B" is closer than this answer so we should choose that over this. But it could be true there's T1 gateways that are owned and configured by the service provider!

E. connects to physical networks - No, this is a T0 North/South thing.

So.... we choose B and C, because "B" is close to being true. This is a poor question.

Selected Answer: BC
T-1 doesn't connect to physical network, it is for Virtual (E-W) Traffic only, and it does NOT support ECMP

Tier-1 Gateway: Owned and configured by tenants 

Page 179 ICMv3.2

Selected Answer: BC
T0 is connected to physical network.

Selected Answer: BC
B&C
T1s are generally owned/configure by tenants for their internal networks

T1s do not connect to a physical network (North-South). This is done via T0s

t1 does not connect to the physical nework

questions.question_text:
An NSX administrator is reviewing syslog and notices that Distributed Firewall Rules hit counts are not being logged.
What could cause this issue?

choices.D: Zero Trust Security is not enabled
choices.A: Syslog is not configured on the ESXi transport node
choices.C: Syslog is not configured on the NSX Manager
choices.B: Distributed Firewall Rule logging is not enabled

choices.A: VM or Bare Metal NSX Edge

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACF
Let's break this down by the answers:

A. VM or Bare Metal NSX Edge

Yes, an NSX Edge can be built as a bare metal server or a VM

B. vShield Edge VM

Wow, vShield is ancient and obsolete... no way this will work with NSX.

C. Bare Metal server

Yes, you can make a bare metal server into a transport node

D. ESXi and Hyper-V

Hyper-V is not supported, so no

E. NSX Edge VM on KVM

Can't put NSX Edge VMs on KVM, so no

F. ESXi and KVM

Yes, ESXi and KVM can both be used as transport nodes.



If you know the answers, great... if you don't, being able to eliminate the wrong answers will get you where you need to go anyway.
